texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're on the latest Fedora release, you're already running lots of modern packages. However, there are those times when you may want to help with testing efforts or try out a new feature in a newer package.
texts.text: If you're on the latest Fedora release, you're already running lots of modern packages. However, there are those times when you may want to help with testing efforts or try out a new feature in a newer package.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of my systems have the
texts.text: Most of my systems have the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: repository enabled in one way or another. This repository contains packages that package maintainers have submitted to become the next stable package in Fedora. For example, if there is a bug fix for nginx, the package maintainer submits the changes and publish a release. That release goes into the testing repositories and must sit for a waiting period or receive sufficient karma ("works for me" responses) to move into stable repositories.
texts.text: repository enabled in one way or another. This repository contains packages that package maintainers have submitted to become the next stable package in Fedora. For example, if there is a bug fix for nginx, the package maintainer submits the changes and publish a release. That release goes into the testing repositories and must sit for a waiting period or receive sufficient karma ("works for me" responses) to move into stable repositories.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One of the easiest ways to get started is to allow a small amount of packages to be installed from the testing repository on a regular basis. Fully enabling the testing repository for all packages can lead to trouble on occasion, especially if a package maintainer discovers a problem and submits a new testing package.
texts.text: One of the easiest ways to get started is to allow a small amount of packages to be installed from the testing repository on a regular basis. Fully enabling the testing repository for all packages can lead to trouble on occasion, especially if a package maintainer discovers a problem and submits a new testing package.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ). This file tells yum and dnf where it should look for packages. The stock testing repository configuration looks like this:
texts.text: ). This file tells yum and dnf where it should look for packages. The stock testing repository configuration looks like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[updates-testing]
name=Fedora $releasever - $basearch - Test Updates
failovermethod=priority
#baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux/updates/testing/$releasever/$basearch/
metalink=https://mirrors.fedoraproject.org/metalink?repo=updates-testing-f$releasever&arch=$basearch
enabled=0
repo_gpgcheck=0
type=rpm
gpgcheck=1
metadata_expire=6h
gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-fedora-$releasever-$basearch
skip_if_unavailable=False
texts.text:
[updates-testing]
name=Fedora $releasever - $basearch - Test Updates
failovermethod=priority
#baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux/updates/testing/$releasever/$basearch/
metalink=https://mirrors.fedoraproject.org/metalink?repo=updates-testing-f$releasever&arch=$basearch
enabled=0
repo_gpgcheck=0
type=rpm
gpgcheck=1
metadata_expire=6h
gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-fedora-$releasever-$basearch
skip_if_unavailable=False

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: By default, the repository is not enabled (
texts.text: By default, the repository is not enabled (

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In this example, let's consider a situation where you want to test the latest kernel packages as soon as they reach the testing repository. We need to make two edits to the repository configuration:
texts.text: In this example, let's consider a situation where you want to test the latest kernel packages as soon as they reach the testing repository. We need to make two edits to the repository configuration:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The repository configuration should now look like this:
texts.text: The repository configuration should now look like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[updates-testing]
name=Fedora $releasever - $basearch - Test Updates
failovermethod=priority
#baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux/updates/testing/$releasever/$basearch/
metalink=https://mirrors.fedoraproject.org/metalink?repo=updates-testing-f$releasever&arch=$basearch
enabled=1
repo_gpgcheck=0
type=rpm
gpgcheck=1
metadata_expire=6h
gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-fedora-$releasever-$basearch
skip_if_unavailable=False
includepkgs=kernel*
texts.text:
[updates-testing]
name=Fedora $releasever - $basearch - Test Updates
failovermethod=priority
#baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux/updates/testing/$releasever/$basearch/
metalink=https://mirrors.fedoraproject.org/metalink?repo=updates-testing-f$releasever&arch=$basearch
enabled=1
repo_gpgcheck=0
type=rpm
gpgcheck=1
metadata_expire=6h
gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-fedora-$releasever-$basearch
skip_if_unavailable=False
includepkgs=kernel*

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One final note:  package maintainers need your feedback  on packages. Positive or negative feedback is very helpful. You can search for the package on  Bodhi  and submit feedback there, or use the
texts.text: One final note:  package maintainers need your feedback  on packages. Positive or negative feedback is very helpful. You can search for the package on  Bodhi  and submit feedback there, or use the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: package. The script will look through your installed package list and query you for feedback on each one.
texts.text: package. The script will look through your installed package list and query you for feedback on each one.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Submitting lots of feedback can earn you some  awesome Fedora Badges !
texts.text: Submitting lots of feedback can earn you some  awesome Fedora Badges !
